course.subject: CENG
course.name: Electrochemical Energy Technologies
course.description: Electrochemical energy conversion and storage technologies such as fuel cells, batteries, supercapacitors, solar cells, electrolyzers, CO2 reduction, etc. help overcome the energy and environmental problems that have become prevalent in our society. This course will focus on the principles and critical materials for each technology. Cutting-edge research areas as well as electrochemistry fundamentals will be discussed in this course.

reviews.author: Farhad
reviews.comment_content:
Syllabus: This course is about electrochemistry, fuel cells, batteries, CO2 reduction, electrolyzers, etc.
Assignments: about 3 in total.
Final project: whatever title you want (actually in the field of electrochemical devices!).
Presentation: 15 min presentation
Attendance: optional
Reading materials: not mandatory.
reviews.comment_teaching:
No TA class.
Teaching is in a good level. Also, the professor has both expertise in industry and academics in his field, and this makes the course more engaging.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm: Not too hard or easy. It's standard, and students will be compared with each other for grading.
Assignments: easy
Project: easy
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is also fair for students. Especially due to the no final exam.

reviews.author: mmmpark
reviews.comment_content: Thorougly covers energy technologies based on electrochemistry. Different types of batteries, fuel cells, etc. Highly useful for those you do research based on electrochemistry.
reviews.comment_teaching: Similar style to UG course. Provides class recordings. Provides powerpoint slides and supplementary readings.
reviews.comment_grading: Highly depend on midterm exam and final term paper/presentation. Assignments doesn't take up much portion.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is not that high. 3 to 4 assignments, term paper (write a review paper about a certain topic, only for PG students), 12 minute presentation, and midterm exam. Midterm exam questions are more difficult than the assignment questions.
